item.title: They Solved the Marfa Lights. Nobody Bothered With What Was Left.
item.description: The official explanation for the Marfa Lights is correct. I want to be clear about that before anything else. Drive down U.S. 67 west of Alpine at night, and your headlights get refracted by the temperature inversion that forms every single evening in the high desert, warm air above and cold air pooling in the valley, exactly the optical conditions required for a Fata Morgana. The cold air bends your light upward. Observers at the state-funded viewing platform nine miles east of Marfa see floating orbs. It’s physics. It’s confirmed. A University of Texas at Dallas team drove down that highway in 2004, flashed their headlights, and watched them appear as mysterious lights from the platform. Atmospheric refraction. Mystery solved.

item.title: They Got the Spectrum. It Still Didn't Help.
item.description: Here is the thing about anomalies in mainstream physics: they get explained eventually. The continental drift people waited decades but it came through. Ball lightning has been documented since the 1600s, is acknowledged in Physical Review Letters and Nature, has eyewitness accounts matching across languages and centuries, got captured by scientific instruments in 2014 - and the field’s current position is still, essentially: we have several theories, none of them quite work, please don’t make this awkward at conferences.
